Situation1: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I stand behind the register, scanning groceries for the few customers trickling in this quiet morning. Each time someone approaches, I smile and greet them, making sure to ask about their day, just as my manager expects. Friendly service, always. But my mind keeps drifting to the voter ID card sitting on my kitchen table. I forgot it this morning, and today is the only time I can swing by home before the polls close tomorrow. If I leave now, I’ll have just enough time to grab it and still make it back before the lunch rush. But if I go, I’ll leave the store short-staffed, and my coworkers will have to cover for me. I can almost hear my manager’s disappointment if I abandon my post, even for a little while. Yet, if I don’t get my ID, I can’t vote, and I’ve always believed in doing my civic duty. The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I feel torn, standing at the register, caught between being a good employee and a responsible citizen.
